title: Artwork by Adolf Hitler up for auction in Nuremberg, Germany
title_page: Artwork by Adolf Hitler up for auction in Nuremberg, Germany | Daily Mail Online
text:
A collection of paintings and drawings made by Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler are going under the hammer in Germany - and they could fetch hundreds of thousands of pounds.
The artwork, which includes watercolours of houses, castles, countryside scenes and town squares, will be sold off in the Bavarian city of Nuremberg.
It comes six months after another collection of his art fetched £286,000 at auction with one work - a painting of Neuschwanstein Castle in Bavaria - selling to a Chinese buyer for £71,000.

Watercolour landscapes, nude portraits and still lifes were among the 14 pieces that went under the hammer at an auction in June, which was also in Nuremburg.
In November a watercolour painted by a young Hitler in 1914 of the city hall in Munich sold for 130,000 euros at a sale organised by the same auction house.
As a budding young artist, Hitler applied to the Vienna Academy of Art but was rejected. He continued to paint however, copying images from postcards that he sold to tourists.
